Long-term effects.
<a href="Orlando%20Figes">Orlando Figes</a> points to the long-term damage Russia suffered:
The <a href="Treaty%20of%20Paris%20%281856%29">Treaty of Paris</a> stood until 1871, when Prussia defeated France in the <a href="Franco-Prussian%20War">Franco-Prussian War</a> of 1870–71. While Prussia and several other German states united to form a powerful <a href="German%20Empire">German Empire</a> in January 1871, the French deposed Emperor Napoleon III and proclaimed the <a href="Third%20French%20Republic">Third French Republic</a> (September 1870). During his reign, Napoleon, eager for the support of the United Kingdom, had opposed Russia over the Eastern Question. Russian interference in the Ottoman Empire did not in any significant manner threaten the interests of France, and France abandoned its opposition to Russia after the establishment of the republic. Encouraged by the new attitude of French diplomacy after the surrenders of the besieged French army at Sedan and later Metz and supported by the German Chancellor <a href="Otto%20von%20Bismarck">Otto von Bismarck</a>, Russia in October 1870 renounced the Black Sea clauses of the treaty agreed to in 1856. As the United Kingdom with Austria could not enforce the clauses, Russia once again established a <a href="Black%20Sea%20Fleet">fleet in the Black Sea</a>.
After being defeated in the Crimean War, Russia feared that <a href="Russian%20Alaska">Russian Alaska</a> would be easily captured in any future war with the British; therefore, Alexander II opted to sell the territory to the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>.
Historian Norman Rich argues that the war was not an accident, but was sought out by the determination of the British and French not to allow Russia an honourable retreat. Both insisted on a military victory to enhance their prestige in European affairs when a non-violent peaceful political solution was available. The war then wrecked the Concert of Europe, which had long kept the peace.
Turkish historian Candan Badem wrote, "Victory in this war did not bring any significant material gain, not even a war indemnity. On the other hand, the Ottoman treasury was nearly bankrupted due to war expenses". Badem adds that the Ottomans achieved no significant territorial gains, lost the right to a navy in the Black Sea, and failed to gain status as a great power.. Further, the war gave impetus to the union of the Danubian principalities and ultimately to their independence.
The treaty punished the defeated Russia, but in the long run, Austria lost the most from the war despite having barely taken part in it. Having abandoned its alliance with Russia, <a href="Austrian%20Empire">Austria</a> remained diplomatically isolated following the war, which contributed to its disastrous defeats in the 1859 <a href="Second%20Italian%20War%20of%20Independence">Franco-Austrian War</a> that resulted in the cession of <a href="Lombardy">Lombardy</a> to the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Sardinia">Kingdom of Sardinia</a> and later in the loss of the Habsburg rule of <a href="Grand%20Duchy%20of%20Tuscany">Tuscany</a> and <a href="Duchy%20of%20Modena%20and%20Reggio">Modena</a>, which meant the end of Austrian influence in peninsular Italy. Furthermore, Russia did not do anything to assist its former ally, Austria, in the 1866 <a href="Austro-Prussian%20War">Austro-Prussian War</a>, when Austria lost <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Lombardy%E2%80%93Venetia">Venetia</a> and, more importantly, its influence in most German-speaking lands. The status of Austria as a great power, with the unifications of <a href="German%20unification">Germany</a> and <a href="Italian%20unification">Italy</a>, now became very precarious. It had to <a href="Ausgleich">compromise</a> with <a href="Hungarians">Hungary</a>; the two countries shared the Danubian Empire and Austria slowly became little more than a German <a href="satellite%20state">satellite</a>. With France now hostile to Germany and gravitating towards Russia, and with Russia competing with the newly renamed <a href="Austro-Hungarian%20Empire">Austro-Hungarian Empire</a> for an increased role in the Balkans at the expense of the Ottoman Empire, the foundations were in place for building the diplomatic alliances that would shape the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a> of 1914.
The Treaty's guarantees to preserve Ottoman territories were broken 21 years later when Russia, exploiting nationalist unrest in the Balkans and seeking to regain lost prestige, once again declared war on the Ottoman Empire on 24 April 1877. In this later <a href="Russo-Turkish%20War%20%281877%E2%80%931878%29">Russo-Turkish War</a> the states of <a href="Romania">Romania</a>, <a href="Serbia">Serbia</a>, and <a href="Montenegro">Montenegro</a> gained international recognition of their independence and <a href="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a> achieved its autonomy from direct Ottoman rule. Russia took over <a href="Southern%20Bessarabia">Southern Bessarabia</a>, lost in 1856. The regions of Batum and Kars, as well as those inhabited by <a href="Adjarians">Adjarians</a> (Muslim <a href="Georgians">Georgians</a>) and <a href="Armenians">Armenians</a>, were also annexed to Russia in the Caucasus. At the same time, "protectors" of the Ottoman Empire Britain received <a href="Cyprus">Cyprus</a> as a colonial possession, while Austria-Hungary occupied and annexed <a href="Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> in 1908. Finally, Ottoman rule in the Balkans ended after the <a href="First%20Balkan%20War">First Balkan War</a> of 1912, when the combined forces of the Balkan States defeated it.
The Crimean War marked the re-ascendancy of France to the position of pre-eminent power on the Continent, the continued decline of the Ottoman Empire and a period of crisis for <a href="Russian%20Empire">Imperial Russia</a>. As Fuller notes, "Russia had been beaten on the Crimean peninsula, and the military feared that it would inevitably be beaten again unless steps were taken to surmount its military weakness." To compensate for its defeat in the Crimean War, the Russian Empire then embarked in more intensive expansion in Asia, partially to restore national pride and partially to distract Britain on the world stage, intensifying the <a href="Great%20Game">Great Game</a>.
The war also marked the demise of the first phase of the <a href="Concert%20of%20Europe">Concert of Europe</a>, the balance-of-power system that had dominated Europe since the <a href="Congress%20of%20Vienna">Congress of Vienna</a> in 1815 and had included France, Russia, Prussia, Austria and the United Kingdom. From 1854 to 1871, the Concert of Europe concept was weakened, leading to the crises that were the <a href="Unification%20of%20Germany">unifications of Germany</a> and <a href="Italian%20unification">of Italy</a>, before a resurgence of great power conferences.

The view of "diplomatic drift" as the cause of the war was first popularised by A. W. Kinglake, who portrayed the British as victims of newspaper sensationalism and duplicitous French and Ottoman diplomacy.
More recently, historians Andrew Lambert and <a href="Winfried%20Baumgart">Winfried Baumgart</a> have argued that Britain was following a geopolitical strategy in aiming to destroy the fledgling Russian Navy, which might challenge the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> for control of the seas, and that the war was also a joint European response to a century of Russian expansion not just southwards but also into Western Europe.
In 1870, Prussia persuaded Russia to remain neutral in the Franco-Prussian war. Bismarck, having declared it impossible to keep 100 million Russians in a humiliated position without sovereign rights to their Black Sea coastline, supported Russia against the Treaty of Paris, and in return, Prussia achieved freedom of action against France in 1870-1871 and inflicted a crushing defeat on it.
Documentation.
Documentation of the war was provided by <a href="William%20Howard%20Russell">William Howard Russell</a>, who wrote for "<a href="The%20Times">The Times</a>" newspaper, and by <a href="Roger%20Fenton">Roger Fenton</a>'s photographs. News from war correspondents reached all of the nations involved in the war and kept the public citizenry of those nations better informed of the day-to-day events of the war than had been the case in any earlier war. The British public was very well informed on the day-to-day realities of the war. After the French extended the telegraph to the coast of the Black Sea in late 1854, news reached <a href="London">London</a> in two days. When the British laid an underwater cable to the Crimean Peninsula in April 1855, news reached London in a few hours. The daily news reports energised public opinion, which brought down the Aberdeen government and carried Lord Palmerston into office as prime minister.
Criticisms and reform.
Historian <a href="R.%20B.%20McCallum">R. B. McCallum</a> points out the war was enthusiastically supported by the British populace as it was happening, but the mood changed very dramatically afterwards. Pacifists and critics were unpopular but:
As the memory of the "Charge of the Light Brigade" demonstrates, the war became an iconic symbol of logistical, medical and tactical failures and mismanagement. Public opinion in Britain was outraged at the logistical and command failures of the war; the newspapers demanded drastic reforms, and parliamentary investigations demonstrated the multiple failures of the Army. The reform campaign was not well organised, and the traditional aristocratic leadership of the Army pulled itself together, and blocked all serious reforms. No one was punished. The outbreak of the <a href="Sepoy%20Mutiny%20of%201857">Sepoy Mutiny in 1857</a> shifted attention to the heroic defence of British interest by the <a href="British%20Army">army</a>, and further talk of reform went nowhere. The demand for professionalisation was achieved by <a href="Florence%20Nightingale">Florence Nightingale</a>, who gained worldwide attention for pioneering and publicising modern nursing while treating the wounded. Another nurse, Jamaican doctor <a href="Mary%20Seacole">Mary Seacole</a>, also made an impact providing care for wounded and dying soldiers. The "Times" war correspondent <a href="William%20Howard%20Russell">William Howard Russell</a> spoke highly of Seacole's skill as a healer, writing "A more tender or skilful hand about a wound or a broken limb could not be found among our best surgeons."
The Crimean War also saw the first tactical use of railways and other modern inventions, such as the electric telegraph, with the first "live" war reporting to "The Times" by William Howard Russell. Some credit Russell with prompting the resignation of the sitting British government through his reporting of the lacklustre condition of British forces deployed in Crimea. Additionally, the telegraph reduced the independence of British overseas possessions from their commanders in London due to such rapid communications. Newspaper readership informed public opinion in the United Kingdom and France as never before. It was the first European war to be photographed. The Russians installed telegraph links to Moscow and St Petersburg during the war, and expanded their rail network south of Moscow after the peace treaty.
The war also employed modern military tactics, such as trenches and blind artillery fire. The use of the <a href="Mini%C3%A9%20ball">Minié ball</a> for shot, coupled with the <a href="rifling">rifling</a> of barrels, greatly increased the range and the damage caused by the allied weapons.
The <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a> system of <a href="sale%20of%20commissions">sale of commissions</a> came under great scrutiny during the war, especially in connection with the <a href="Battle%20of%20Balaclava">Battle of Balaclava</a>, which saw the ill-fated <a href="Charge%20of%20the%20Light%20Brigade">Charge of the Light Brigade</a>. This scrutiny later led to the abolition of the sale of commissions.
During the Crimean war, the first use of steam armoured ships in the military history took place. Three <a href="D%C3%A9vastation-class%20ironclad%20floating%20battery">"Dévastation"-class floating batteries</a> were successfully used against the sea fortress of Kinburn in the autumn of 1855. The direct initiator of this military innovation was the French Emperor Napoleon III. The military threat of the use of this new weapon in the campaign of 1856 contributed to Russia's acceptance of the unfavourable conditions of the Paris treaty of 1856.
<a href="Michael%20Faraday">Michael Faraday</a> received a proposal from the British government to develop chemical weapons for use in the siege of Sevastopol. Faraday categorically refused and publicly condemned the proposal and his position contributed to the rejection of the development and use of these weapons during the Crimean war.
The Crimean War was a contributing factor in the Russian <a href="Emancipation%20reform%20of%201861">abolition of serfdom</a> in 1861: Tsar <a href="Alexander%20II%20of%20Russia">Alexander II</a> (Nicholas I's son and successor) saw the military defeat of the Russian serf-army by free troops from Britain and France as proof of the need for emancipation. The Crimean War also led to the realisation by the Russian government of its technological inferiority, in military practices as well as weapons.
Meanwhile, Russian military medicine saw dramatic progress: <a href="Nikolay%20Ivanovich%20Pirogov">Nikolay I. Pirogov</a>, known as the father of Russian field surgery, developed the use of <a href="anaesthetics">anaesthetics</a>, plaster casts, enhanced <a href="amputation">amputation</a> methods, and five-stage <a href="triage">triage</a> in Crimea, among other things.
The war also led to the establishment of the <a href="Victoria%20Cross">Victoria Cross</a> in 1856 (backdated to 1854), the British Army's first universal award for valour. 111 medals were awarded.
The British issued the <a href="Crimea%20Medal">Crimea Medal</a> with 5 clasps, and the <a href="Baltic%20Medal">Baltic Medal</a>, as well as Valour medals, including the newly created <a href="Distinguished%20Conduct%20Medal">Distinguished Conduct Medal</a>, the <a href="Turkish%20Crimea%20Medal">Turkish Crimea Medal</a>, the French did not issue a campaign medal, issuing <a href="M%C3%A9daille%20militaire">Médaille militaire</a> and <a href="Legion%20of%20Honour">Legion of Honour</a> for bravery, Sardinia also <a href="Sardinian%20Crimea%20Medal">issued a medal</a>. Russia issued a Defence of Sevastopol, and a Crimean War medal.
